Question: How likely is it that you would recommend Abcam as a place to work?

I think Abcam is a good place to work and I will continue to recommend it. I think that Abcam does a good job at encouraging employees to get involved in a range of activities that they would not do otherwise e.g. passport to wellness, work experience week. I feel that this encouragement motivates people to take on further responsibilities to better the work environment such as representing the team in cross functional group projects like lab supermarket.
However, with the promotion cycle being changed to once a year instead of every 6 months I find it hard to stay motivated to grow my career here. It is difficult to stay motivated to grow my responsibilities and skills at Abcam when statistically that growth will not be recognised in the form of promotion for a few years.

In my particular case, my ability to remain working in Abcam, as I would like to do, is dependent on having a straightforward conversation with HR in relation to work visas. Unfortunately, I have not gotten an answer to my information requests. I understand it is a difficult topic, but at least a confirmation that my questions and concerns have been received and are being evaluated, would be very helpful.

Setting clear goals within the IHM team can give a clear sense of direction and focus for the team. In our team, we have a clear sense of what needs to be done that given week and we have a very clear understanding of which process takes the longest and which should be done first. 
But what else can drive us better? How can we make our processes LEANer? Do we want more proficiency in cross-training? Then how long do we keep cross-trained associates in other departments without losing support in their current team? Do we want higher pass rates? How do we increase our order output to customers per week?

Managers, leaders, and advanced associates should foster a symbiotic learning and teaching environment. Make it like school again where everyone, including managers are learning new topics every day. Treat the EUG site as proofing grounds for radical LEAN concepts in manufacturing to increase productivity and employee engagement through contact and listening activities. This can be done better with status, personal feelings, and position titles set aside. Examples include having more associates presenting their work at meetings, and regular gemba walks which are occurring. 
In the EUG team, we should also uplift and challenge future leaders. Our team comprises of people that have been here 3-7 years. We have people that are growing, particularly women, and management should prioritize lifting these potential leaders. Especially if they at a point where they truly know their worth in the business. Question: How likely is it you would recommend Abcam as a place to work?
Comment:
I started helping with recruitment within the team last year, we had an internal hire which went fine and I was excited to help with our latest vacancy as we’re always busy and have a planning backlog constantly building up due to capacity, but our recent attempt at an external hire was an absolute chaotic mess which was undermined and disrupted every step of the way by HR, talent acquisition, and others. 

•	In the initial stages we had a CV forwarded to us from another previous vacancy, only to find out that the hiring manager for that vacancy specifically requested that CV NOT be forwarded for the role as they clearly were not happy with him.
•	When we rejected that candidate after a phone interview the TA rep did not reject him, and instead arranged another phone interview. We asked her to cancel it, which was not acted on for a day, then when she was prompted again said it was too late. We then had to do a "fake" interview with a candidate we already rejected, wasting his and our time.
•	When the process was about to finish, the DAY BEFORE sending the job offer out we were told to pause the process as the job may be cancelled, after 6 weeks of recruiting and looking over more than a hundred applicants.
•	When the job was finally approved (again) the pay offer sent out to him was massively below what other recent new hires were offered in the same role (despite them having almost identical experience to him) and was said to him in his interview, as in a 10%+ difference.
•	I was told emergency discussions were had to increase the pay offer before the candidate rejected the job offer, then the next day when I reviewed the communications with the candidate on SmartRecruiters our TA rep had instead told the candidate there would be no pay increase.
 
This candidate has significant experience and expertise using equipment our lab is heavily reliant on, which is a rarity for this level of role. It will reduce our training time massively, and allow for him to be put on production alone much quicker than any other candidate and help with capacity at a time where we have a large backlog with planning – the money savings from that alone likely outweigh the ~£2000 HR is quibbling over. I can't imagine him staying here long on the salary he was offered, which is less than some of our new starters got 2.5 years ago.

This whole situation has been stressful and miserable, and honestly it feels like it was being actively sabotaged for reasons unknown, I'm not sure if I intend to help with any future hires if this kind of behaviour is considered acceptable by Abcam.

It's only a matter of time until this new associate finds out he's being payed far below what all the other Research Associates are, he'll no doubt feel humiliated and angry about it and we have no justification to provide him.
